Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Carter’s voice rose, thick with frustration. “You people call every week! How do I know this offer is even real?” As a telemarketer, I was trained to stay calm, to handle objections, to reassure him with practiced explanations. But my mind kept drifting to the courthouse, where in less than an hour, I was supposed to represent a client at a minor hearing. The stakes weren’t high, but as an advocate, I owed my client my full attention and preparation. Yet here I was, caught in a script, trying to soothe an irate customer who deserved honesty, while my briefcase sat unopened by my desk. My supervisor expected me to close the call with a sale, but my client expected me to stand up for them in court. I felt my heart race, torn between the demands of two worlds, each pulling at me with its own urgency, and I wondered which expectation I would fail first.
